McCurdy}} {{Infobox CanadianMP | name=Howard McCurdy |image=Howard mccurdy.jpg | birth_date=December 10, 1932 | birth_place= [[London, Ontario|London]], [[Ontario]] | death_date= | death_place= | residence= [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]], [[Ontario]] | riding1=[[Windsor—Walkerville]] | term_start1=1984 | term_end1=1988 | predecessor1= [[Mark MacGuigan]] | successor1=riding dissolved | riding2=[[Windsor—St. Clair|Windsor—Lake St. Clair]] | term_start2=1988 | term_end2=1993 | predecessor2=first member | successor2=[[Shaughnessy Cohen]] | party=[[New Democratic Party (Canada)|New Democrat]] | footnotes= | spouse= | religion= | profession=biochemist, professor |}} '''Howard Douglas McCurdy''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|OOnt}} (born December 10, 1932) is a retired [[Canada|Canadian]] politician and university professor. Born in [[London, Ontario]], McCurdy studied at the [[University of Western Ontario]], where he received a [[Bachelor of Arts]], and later at [[Assumption University (Windsor)|Assumption University]], where he received a [[Bachelor of Science]]. He was awarded a Master of Science and a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in microbiology and chemistry from [[Michigan State University]]. McCurdy has also served for a time as Michigan State University's president of the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People|National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP)]]. From 1979 to 1984, McCurdy served the city of [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]] as an [[alderman]] and later joined the [[New Democratic Party (Canada)|New Democratic Party]], eventually becoming the party's first [[African-Canadian]] [[Member of Parliament]]. He served as the MP for the [[electoral district (Canada)|riding]] of [[Windsor—Walkerville]] from the [[Canadian federal election, 1984|1984 election]] until riding redistribution in 1988. In the [[Canadian federal election, 1988|1988 election]] he was reelected in the new riding of [[Windsor—St. Clair|Windsor—Lake St. Clair]], where he served until his defeat in the [[Canadian federal election, 1993|1993 federal election]]. He was also a candidate for the party leadership in the [[New Democratic Party leadership elections#1989 NDP Leadership Convention Results|1989 leadership convention]] which selected [[Audrey McLaughlin]]. McCurdy campaigned for the [[Ontario New Democratic Party]] nomination in [[Windsor—Sandwich]] in the buildup to the [[Ontario general election, 1995|1995 provincial election]], but was unexpectedly defeated by [[Arlene Rousseau]]. McCurdy had been endorsed by [[Premier of Ontario|Premier]] [[Bob Rae]], while Rousseau was an ally of party dissidents such as [[Peter Kormos]]. In 2003, he supported [[Bill Blaikie]]'s campaign for NDP leader. ==Awards== McCurdy has received many awards, including the [[Canadian Centennial Medal]] in 1967, the [[Queen's Silver Jubilee Medal]] in 1977, and in 2001 the [[J. S. Woodsworth]] Award for Human Rights.<ref>Keith A. P. Sandiford, ''A Black Studies Primer: Heroes and Heroines of the African Diaspora'', Hansib Publications, 2008, p. 304.</ref> In 2012, McCurdy was made a member of the [[Order of Ontario]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.ontario.ca/mci/en/2012/01/27-appointees-named-to-ontarios-highest-honour.html|title=27 Appointees Named To Ontario's Highest Honour}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} In 2013, McCurdy was made a member of the Order of Canada. ==External links== *{{CanParlbio|ID=5d32f582-9e97-4d15-86ad-267bcbd283c9}} {{Persondata | NAME =McCurdy, Howard | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Canadian politician | DATE OF BIRTH =December 10, 1932 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[London, Ontario|London]], [[Ontario]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:McCurdy, Howard}} [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Michigan State University alumni]] [[Category:Members of the House of Commons of Canada from Ontario]] [[Category:Members of the Order of Ontario]] [[Category:New Democratic Party (Canada) MPs]] [[Category:Black Canadian politicians]] [[Category:Windsor, Ontario city councillors]] [[Category:University of Windsor alumni]] [[Category:University of Western Ontario alumni]]
